body: To the Editor: Your article ''Swept Away,'' a sympathetic image of the White Sands community (Oct. 10) reports (prematurely, I hope) on the ''death of a neighborhood.'' If this comes to pass, then the executioners will be the Home Depot Corporation, the top administration officials and the local politicians. White Sands's history is colorful but
title: A Dying Neighborhood Has Many Executioners

body: Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' featuring 300 to 500 live, free-flying tropical butterflies from Central, South and North America, housed in a vivarium that approximates their natural habitat; through February. title: SPARE TIMES

body: AS the cries and curses of thousands of freshly ticketed double-parkers fill the air, victims of the city's new Operation Move Along, it might comfort them to know there is one man who not only feels their pain but has dedicated his life to combating it. Meet Louis Camporeale, 39, a mild-mannered computer analyst from Gravesend, Brooklyn. He
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Circling in an '87 Honda, It's the Parking Pal

body: ELVIA SUTER was strolling down Bay 54th Street, a dead-end block in the tiny Brooklyn community of White Sands, when she stopped and gestured toward a 50-foot oak tree. An abandoned blue Chrysler filled with garbage was parked next to it. ''See this tree here?'' asked Ms. Suter, a vigorous 82-year-old with salt-and-pepper hair. ''When my son was 8,
title: Swept Away

body: IT wasn't actually their idea to tell the newspapers about what they call their wedding, say New York City Police Officers Elizabeth Bryant and Marilyn Trapanotto. The president of the Gay Officers' Action League approached them a couple of days before the ceremony in June 1997, saying it would be a good thing, so they agreed. As it turned out, Ms.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; For a Gay Officer, First Love, Then Malice

body: It has stood on a busy stretch of road in the Bronx for almost a century, a city landmark and a beacon of promise to the children who clamored down its great halls. It served as an anchor of civic pride for a community defined by waves of immigration and poverty. But for two years, Public School 31 in Mott Haven has been idle, its ornate five-story
title: These Grand Old Schools Nurtured a City; Some Say It Is Time To Tear Them Down

body: FIRST Ambrose Afondeur took scuba diving lessons in the Y.M.C.A. pool on the Upper West Side. Then he did what most other aspiring divers who live in New York City do. For the four open-water dives required for his certification, he jetted off to a warmer clime: Maui, Hawaii. Later, it was the coral reefs off the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean
title: The Urban Deep

body: Great Rubel Robbery Q. The building where I work, at Bay 19th Street and Cropsey Avenue in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, was once occupied by the Rubel Coal and Ice Company. I understand that a famous armed robbery occurred there in the 1930's. Do you have details? A. Just after noon on Aug. 21, 1934, an armored truck pulled up outside the 90-foot-long
title: F.Y.I.

body: A 37-year-old man was found shot dead yesterday in his home in Gravesend, Brooklyn, with his hands bound and a pillowcase over his head, the police said. The victim, Peter Lanza, had a history of arrests for drug and fireworks possession, officials said, and at the time of his death he was wearing an electronic ankle bracelet because he was under
title: Brooklyn Parolee Found Bound and Fatally Shot in His Home

body: Three people were killed early yesterday morning when a fast-moving fire that officials said was intentionally set tore through a Staten Island row house. The house, at 190 Bay Street in the Tompkinsville section, caught fire shortly after 3 A.M., said Joseph Leoncavallo, a Fire Department spokesman. In addition to those killed, he said, two
title: Three Die in Staten Island Arson; Brooklyn Fire Kills One

body: For three and a half months, a Ukrainian freighter has been stranded in New York Harbor, her cargo holds and fuel tanks empty, her master awaiting orders that never come, her 26-member crew idle and recently unpaid, food and supplies dwindling -- a ship dead in the water, caught in a ghostly maritime limbo. Riding at anchor in Gravesend Bay off
title: Crew of Ukrainian Freighter Stranded in New York Harbor

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ABIGAIL ADAMS SMITH MUSEUM, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. The structure, built in 1799 as the carriage house for the estate of Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, was also the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. The current exhibition, ''Smith's Folly: 200 Years of History, 60 Years of Preservation,'' includes a
title: SPARE TIMES

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN CHELSEA $425,000 144 West 27th Street 1,900-sq.-ft. raw-space condo in a prewar building; elevator, restored maple floors, 11-ft. ceilings, new windows; common
title: Residential Sales

body: LIKE it's namesake, Bath, the spa town in England, Bath Beach is a tranquil place. But it is no longer the resort area it was a century ago. The beach itself was eradicated in a postwar building boom, and largely replaced by housing on a landfill. Now it is primarily residential with a walkway along the waterfront and a view of Coney Island across
title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Bath Beach, Brooklyn; Once a Bayfront Resort, Now Residential

body: A top Sanitation Department official signaled yesterday that the city was open to working with community groups on how to export its residential garbage, suggesting that it might not be committed to building huge waste transfer stations. Instead, the official, Deputy Commissioner Martha Hirst, said the city would consider using only the eight
title: Sanitation Department Hints of Flexibility on Plans to Export Trash

body: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the installation of a speed bump in Gravesend, Brooklyn, misspelled the surname of the chairman of Community Board 15, who complained that the board had not been notified. He is John E. Nikas, not Nickas.
title: Corrections

body: TURKEY has never been on the main tourist route that has been well trampled by Americans herding through Provence, Italy or the Greek isles. As a result, Turkish cooking has never really achieved the vogue of other Mediterranean cuisines. Just as this ancient country geographically links Europe and the Middle East, its cooking stretches from the
title: $25 AND UNDER; Between the Tastes of Greece and the Middle East
